Speaker: benny
Dialogue: And I didn't tell Dupree that I'd give you your job back... All I said was that I'd be glad to talk to you if you said the right thing... Do you have something to say?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Mr. Giacomo, when one of the white guys has come off a double shift and says he's too tired to work overtime, you don't fire him.

Speaker: benny
Dialogue: Fella, what'd I tell ya? If you're not willing to give a little extra, Champion can't use you.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I want my job back, Mr. Giacomo. I need to work and I need a good job.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: No, that's not all... I need money so that I can pay my mortgage and eat... I need a house to live in and a place to raise children... I need to buy clothes so I can--

Speaker: benny
Dialogue: I'm sorry, fella, but I gotta get back to work...

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Ezekiel, Mr. Giacomo.

Speaker: benny
Dialogue: Hunh?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: My name is Ezekiel... Ezekiel Rawlins.

Speaker: benny
Dialogue: S'cuse me, Ezekiel.

Speaker: joppy
Dialogue: Hey, watch the marble!   Dammit, what'd I tell you?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Joppy, how much they payin' out there at McDonell Douglas?

Speaker: joppy
Dialogue: I don't know.   Don't it say--

Speaker: joppy
Dialogue: Easy, come on over here. This here's somebody I want ya to meet... Come on. This here's a friend of mine.

Speaker: joppy
Dialogue: Yeah, Easy.   This here's Mr. Albright.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: You can call me Dewitt, Easy.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: How ya doin'?

Speaker: joppy
Dialogue: Mr. Albright and me goes back to before the war when I was still in the fight game.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Ever seen this guy fight...? Any time Joppy Shag stepped in the ring you knew you were gonna see some real knock-down-drag-out- fisticuffs... Where you from, Easy?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Houston.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Houston... Joppy's hometown.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: So I hear you need a job.

Speaker: joppy
Dialogue: Aw yeah, Easy always tryin' to do better. Got his high school certificate from night school. He's threatenin' up on some college. And he's one of the few colored men around here who owns his own house. Shoot, he pays a mortgage every month just like a white man.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Property owner, hunh?

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: These big companies, don't give a damn, do they?

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: If you need a job, drop by this address at seven tonight.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: What kind of work you do?

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: I do favors... I do favors for friends. Drop by.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Who the hell is that, Joppy?

Speaker: joppy
Dialogue: Just somebody I know... A bidness man.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: What kinda business?

Speaker: joppy
Dialogue: Oh, I don't ask him all that. He comes in here every so often looking for somebody to do a little job for him... He pays good.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: In other words, he's a gangster.

Speaker: joppy
Dialogue: I didn't say that... But if there's a dollar laying in the street I don't think he'll let a little dirt stop him from picking it up. If you worried about making that house note this month, maybe you wanna pay him a call. All them pretty girls you be with ain't gonna buy you a house.

Speaker: joppy
Dialogue: Sound like he just wants you to keep your eyes open for somebody... He'll pay you whether you see anything or not... If it was me I'd take that man's money and go on about my bidness... Ain't nothin' to worry about.

Speaker: woodcutter
Dialogue: Want me to knock down some of them trees back there for you?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: No... Just leave the trees alone.

Speaker: security guard
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I'm looking for, uh...

Speaker: security guard
Dialogue: We only take deliveries between nine and six...

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: No, no... I...

Speaker: security guard
Dialogue: Yes, we do!   Now you'd better leave.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Uh... Albright!

Speaker: security guard
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I'm here to see Mr. Albright. DeWitt Albright!

Speaker: security guard
Dialogue: Where's your delivery?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I have an appointment -- I'm supposed to meet him.

Speaker: security guard
Dialogue: Did he give you a note to come in here after hours?

Speaker: security guard
Dialogue: Well, did he?   Because if he didn't--

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Forget it, man. Next time I see him I'll just tell him you wouldn't let me in.

Speaker: security guard
Dialogue: Hold on.

Speaker: security guard
Dialogue: Across that way to the left and down the stairs...

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Hey, man!    What's wrong with you?

Speaker: tall man
Dialogue: Mr. Rawlins, put your hands up a little from your sides, please.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Keep your hands to yourself. I don't let no man feel on me like that.

Speaker: tall man
Dialogue: Don't worry, Manny. He's okay. Just a little shaky.  Let him know.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Easy.

Speaker: tall man
Dialogue: He doesn't want us to touch him.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Leave it, Shariff. I just wanted to make sure he was solo.

Speaker: shariff
Dialogue: You're the boss.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: You guys can go now. Easy and I have some business.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Have a seat, Mr. Rawlins.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Your friends, hunh?

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Like you, Easy. I need a little help? I give 'em a call... Drink?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: One thing I like about working for myself... I always have a bottle on the table... You wanna drink with me? Fine. You don't? Door's right behind you... Joppy tells me you're a war hero... Said you went in with Patton.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: So, you want the job?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Depends on what kind of job. I don't want to get mixed up in nothing.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Walk out the door in the morning, Easy, and you're mixed up in something. Only thing that matters is if you're mixed up to the top or not.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I mean I don't wanna get mixed up with the law...

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Neither one of us wants to get mixed up in that. That's just rich people trying to keep me and you in our place.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: I'm looking for somebody for a friend.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: She leave him?

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Evidently... You know how it is with women, Easy... Happens to the best of us...

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I ain't never heard of her before. I wouldn't know how to find a woman like that.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: That's a shame.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: See, Daphne has a predilection for the company of Negroes. She likes jazz and pigs feet and dark meat, know what I mean.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: So you think she might be down in Watts.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: I'm sure of it. But I can't go looking for her myself because I'm not of the right persuasion, so to speak. I've been asking Joppy for over a week, but all he could do was introduce me to you.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: What do you want me to do?

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Just get a location on her. Mr. Carter wants to make up with her...

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: That's all.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: That's all.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: One hundred dollars, and I pay in advance.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I just have to tell you where she is?

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: That's right. And keep it, you know, confidential...

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Joppy tells me you used to frequent an illegal club down on Eighty- ninth and Central. Somebody saw Daphne there a few nights ago. You could start tonight.

Speaker: drunk
Dialogue: Hey, colored brother. I need you to do somethin' for me--

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: I just paid these damn cops and they still roustin' my customers. Well, that's what he gets for being with that white woman.

Speaker: drunk
Dialogue: Come on, brother help me...

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: Don't worry 'bout him. I rung Junior ten minutes ago to come get him.

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: I ain't got nobody tonight but Lips and his trio -- Holiday came through here last Tuesday.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Yeah?

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: Where's he at?

Speaker: hattie
Dialogue: Over there. Let Easy in upstairs and when these cops leave throw his ass out.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Hey, Junior.    What's goin' on?

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: Not too much.    But stick around.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: You got a cigarette?

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: Sure.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Damn! How do you smoke these things?

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: Don't you hafta work tomorrow?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Naw.    I got fired.

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: The last time I heard these fellas playin' tonight was back in Houston, the night your ole buddy Mouse had to pull me up off your ass.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: That's the way you remember it, hunh?

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: Hell, that's the way it was.

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: When you gonna admit that you helped Mouse kill old man Navrochet?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Aw, man, get off that. I ain't had nothin' to do with that.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Boy, it's happenin' tonight. Where's all the white women at?

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: I don't pay them white girls no mind.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Yeah... I bet you don't.

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: That's right. Just like you didn't help mouse kill his stepfather.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Go on, man.

Speaker: junior
Dialogue: Hey, Easy. Did you help him kill his stepbrother, too?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Alphonso Jenkins!

Speaker: alphonso
Dialogue: Hey, Easy!

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Hey, man, you seen a girl named Dahlia or somethin'... White girl supposed to be somethin' to look at.

Speaker: alphonso
Dialogue: Naw, but if I see her I'm gonna keep her to myself.

Speaker: rita
Dialogue: Hey, Baby.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Hey, Rita!  What do they see in you?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Hey, Lewis. Gimme a couple glasses and a pail of ice and send a quart of bourbon over there to Odell's table.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Hey, Odell.

Speaker: odell
Dialogue: Easy.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: How's it going tonight?

Speaker: odell
Dialogue: Well... It's goin' alright.   It sure is goin'.

Speaker: dupree
Dialogue: You ain't jumped outta no windows yet?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Not yet, Dupree.

Speaker: dupree
Dialogue: Miss you down at the plant... You know Coretta, don't ya?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Hey, Coretta, how are ya?

Speaker: odell
Dialogue: Oh, my goodness.

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: Could we sit down with y'all?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Sure.   Sure.

Speaker: dupree
Dialogue: You know Benny just wants you to say you're sorry, Easy. And he'll give you your job back.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I'm a sorry man, all right. Any man without his paycheck is sorry.

Speaker: dupree
Dialogue: I got it, Easy. Your money ain't no good up in here.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Naw, Dupree.    This one's mine--

Speaker: dupree
Dialogue: You sure?   You the one outta work.

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: And you're the one ain't never got no money.

Speaker: dupree
Dialogue: Aw, Baby...  Get us another couple glasses.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Either one of y'all seen a white girl named Dahlia or somethin' with a 'D'?

Speaker: dupree
Dialogue: Hey, Coretta got a new job at the phone company.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Hey, you goin' home, Odell?

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: He used to play till the cock crowed. But that ole cock don't crow nearly so much now...

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Think I'm gonna head out.

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: You be sorry if you go.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I think I'd be more sorry if I stay...

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: Daphne sleep by now. You can't get none of that tonight.

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: You been telling everybody Dahlia, but her name is Daphne.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: You know her?

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: Throw him in there on the bed, Easy.

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: Throwed him outta his place, 'cause he couldn't pay the rent. I shouldn't even let him sleep here.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Damn...

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I need a cigarette.

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: That all you need?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Coretta, sun catch me tip-toein' out your door and no tellin' what your neighbors say...

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: Dupree run through his money, fall asleep on me. And you just gonna walk out on me like I was dog food...

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: You got a man in the other room... Why don't you tell me 'bout your friend Daphne?

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: Why you keep askin' 'bout her? Colored women ain't good enough for you no more?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: What if he hears somethin'?

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: Oh yeah, daddy. You hittin' my spot! Oh yeah... yeah!

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: Oooh, that's just too good, Easy.

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: I can't give up that much love, daddy, not the way things is.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: What things?

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: You know, Dupree's right there in the next room.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Forget about him! You got me goin', Coretta!

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: But it ain't right, Easy. Here I am doin' this right in the next room and all you doin' is nosin' after my friend Daphne...

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Daphne?  Oh, yeah... I ain't after her, baby. That's just a job.

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: What job?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Man wants me to find her.

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: What man?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Who cares, what man?   I don't want nobody but you...

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: But Daphne's my friend--

Speaker: coretta
Dialogue: Oh, baby. Oh, daddy, you hittin' my spot! Oh, yeah...

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: "Since Etta Mae has left me and I am a bachelor I figured I could come out and visit and we burn down the town...

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Drive to the trainyard, Easy! Let's dump this damn thing.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: This ain't your friend's car? What'd you do Mouse?

Speaker: mouse
Dialogue: Just drive this sumbitch!

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Bye, Easy!

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Where you goin', Sophie?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Back to Texas... It's too fast for me out here.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Get away from there!

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Hello?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Mr. Albright, is that you?

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Sure is, Easy. What's shakin'?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I got what you want.   She's with--

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Hold on to that, Easy. I like to look a man in the face when we do business. Meet me at the Fisherman's Pier in Malibu at the hamburger stand in an hour.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Uh... I don't know about that Mr. Albright -- Mr. Albright?

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: It's pretty out here, huh?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Yeah.   It's all right.

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: I'm from Des Moines in Iowa.    Where are you from?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Huh?... Uh... Texas...

Speaker: girl
Dialogue: Do they have an ocean in Texas?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: The Gulf, they have the Gulf.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I think they're looking for you.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Who cares? My sister brought me 'cause my parents made her. All she wants to do is make out with Herman and smoke cigarettes.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Leave him alone, Herman!   We were just talking!

Speaker: herman
Dialogue: You were, huh?  We don't need you talking to our women.

Speaker: football
Dialogue: Hey!   What's wrong?

Speaker: herman
Dialogue: Nigger's trying to pick up Barbara.

Speaker: barbara
Dialogue: Leave him alone! We were just talking about the ocean!

Speaker: barbara's sister
Dialogue: Barbara!

Speaker: football
Dialogue: Hey, fella, what's wrong with you?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I don't want no trouble.

Speaker: football
Dialogue: You already got trouble, boy.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Listen... I was just being polite.

Speaker: herman
Dialogue: No, you weren't. You were talkin' about the ocean!

Speaker: football
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: I want to see brains.    I want you to die for me.

Speaker: football
Dialogue: I'm sorry, sir.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: The question is: "Are you sorry enough?"

Speaker: football
Dialogue: Yessir.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Then prove it... Show him... Get down on your knees and suck his peter.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I think he got the point--

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: You heard me.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Son of a gun. You were gonna do it, weren't you?

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Sick bastard.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Get out of here. You call the cops, I'll kill ya!

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: I don't think they'd dare call the cops.  But it'll cost me a few bucks if they do.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: What you got, Easy?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: You sure no harm is gonna come to that woman 'cause of me?

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Course not. Mr. Carter wants to buy her a gold ring and live happily ever after -- What do ya got?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Woman told me she's with a man named Frank Green.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: He's got an apartment at the Skyler Arms on Skyler and Eighty-third.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Anything else?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Frank's a gangster. A hijacker... Liquor and cigarettes. He's real good with a knife.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Ever seen him in action?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Naw.   I just heard about him.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Here's another hundred.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Buy ya a burger, Easy?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: No thanks, Mr. Albright.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: How come you let those boys get around you like that? War hero should have been able to pick 'em off one by one before they got you against the rail.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I don't kill children.

Speaker: albright
Dialogue: Take it easy.

Speaker: skinny man
Dialogue: Mr. Rawlins.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: skinny man
Dialogue: Mr. Rawlins, I'm Miller and this is my partner, Mason.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: We want you to come with us.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: You'll see.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: You arresting me?

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: You'll see.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I got a right to know why you're taking--

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: You got a right to fall down and break your face, nigger. You got a right to die.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Ezekiel Rawlins.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Yes, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: We can take off the cuffs if you wanna cooperate.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I'm cooperating.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Where were you this morning at about five A.M.?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: He means--

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: --this morning.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I don't know... I was out drinkin' and I helped carry a friend home. I could've been on my way home... I don't know... I didn't look at a clock...

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: He didn't look at a clock.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: You were drinkin' down on Eighty- ninth and Central... At an illegal club called John's, weren't you?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: You may as well answer 'cause you got bigger troubles than us bustin' an illegal bar, Ezekiel.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: What do you mean?    What's goin' on?

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: Means we can take your black ass out behind the station and put a bullet in your head.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Now. What time did you leave Coretta James' house this morning?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I guess about five... five- thirty...

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: Sit down.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Why, I'm gonna sit down and you keep trying to knock me down?

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Did you go back and see Miss James later in the day?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: No, sir.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Did you and Dupree Brouchard have words over Miss James?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: You heard 'im. Did you two argue over Coretta James?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Naw.   He was asleep.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: She went to sleep too, Ezekiel. But she won't be waking up...

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Where'd you go when you left Miss James' house?

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: You heard him, where'd you go?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I went home with a hangover...

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Get up slow... Real fuckin' slow or you know what's gonna happen.

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: Okay.   Let's take him out back.

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: No.   Let's go.

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: Bullshit, I'm gonna blow his--

Speaker: miller
Dialogue: Let's go!

Speaker: mason
Dialogue: Son-of-a-bitch! Son-of-a-bitch!

Speaker: officer
Dialogue: Hey, Buddy!... It's a long walk... why don't you let us give you a ride?

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: Ezekiel, hold on.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: Come on, fella. Somebody in the back wants to talk to you.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I don't have time right now.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: Jump in. We'll take you.    My boss wants to talk to you.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: Come on. If we wanted to hurt you it would have already happened...

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: I can see that the police roughed you up a bit... That's a terrible practice of theirs which has to change, Mr. Rawlins... Has to change.

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: She was beaten. And died from a heavy blow to the back of the head, Mr. Rawlins.

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: The evening's events have caught my adopted son and I quite off guard... My household was asleep when we got the call that the police had a suspect in Coretta James' murder... Did you know that she was a friend of mine, Mr. Rawlins!?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: No I didn't, Mr. Teran.

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: Oh, you know who I am?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: I read the papers.   You're runnin' for mayor.

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: I am the next mayor, Mr. Rawlins... And luckily for you, a friend of the Negro... When I arrived at the station I knew right off that you were being improperly detained as is Coretta's boyfriend, Dupree Brouchard. It's this sort of thing that my administration will not tolerate, Mr. Rawlins. Absolutely will not...

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: Yes... Coretta answered phones for a while in my campaign office on 103rd and Western. In fact my people got her a job in the phone company. So when I heard what had happened I got out of bed immediately, personally because of my concern... Was anyone there with you Mr. Rawlins besides Mr. Dupree Brouchard?... Any... other friends of Coretta's?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: No, sir...

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: No young lady perhaps?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Nobody...

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: Of course not, Mr. Rawlins. And why should you tell a man whom you've only just met. But, believe me, Mr. Rawlins. You can trust me.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: There was no one else.

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: Well don't worry, Mr. Rawlins... I won't tolerate your being harassed... You or any of my constituency -- I was a city councilman in the Watts area for two terms with a large contingent of colored -- I value all of my supporters equally... humble though they may be -- where can we drop you, Mr. Rawlins?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: You can let me out here.

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: Are you sure, Mr. Rawlins? This must be quite out of your way.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: It's okay.

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: Norman, pull the car over.

Speaker: teran
Dialogue: Mr. Rawlins, may I offer you cab fare?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: No thanks.

Speaker: coretta's voice
Dialogue: You be sorry if you go...  I can't give up that much love, daddy, not the way things is.

Speaker: coretta's voice
Dialogue: Oh yeah, daddy. You hittin' my spot... Oh yeah... oh yeah...

Speaker: coretta's voice
Dialogue: Oh, that's just too good, Easy.   Oh daddy... oh yeah...

Speaker: coretta's voice
Dialogue: Oh, baby. Oh, daddy, yeah... Oh yeah!! Oh Yea-a-h!!

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Hello? Is this Mr. Rawlins?

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Who is this?

Speaker: voice
Dialogue: Daphne... Daphne Monet...

Speaker: daphne
Dialogue: You're looking for me.

Speaker: daphne
Dialogue: I think you should come and talk to me, Mr. Rawlins... alone.

Speaker: easy
Dialogue: Look, it's late--
